abstract: Gretchen Morgenson Fair Game column examines criticism in financial world of Security and Exchange Commission's push to try more cases in its internal administrative courts; argues that while courts are more efficient, their uses raises questions of fairness, not only because they lack important procedural powers, but also because they have far higher conviction rate than SEC cases tried in federal courts.
lead_paragraph: The agency’s use of internal trials has raised questions about fairness because defendants may not have all the same rights they have in federal court.

headline.main: Crying Foul on Plans to Expand the S.E.C.’s In-House Court System
headline.print_headline: Crying Foul on In-House S.E.C. Courts
